scalesUsed.application: Main chord progressions and melodic content

mainProgression.description: Classic rock progression using power chords in E major

sectionProgressions.romanNumerals: I - I - V - V - IV - IV - I - I
sectionProgressions.description: Extended verse progression with longer chord durations
Driving chorus progression with quick changes

techniques.name: Power Chords
techniques.description: The backbone of the song - E5, B5, and A5 power chords form the main progression. Essential for achieving the authentic rock sound.

details.fingeringTips: Use index and ring finger for 2-string power chords, keep pinky relaxed

techniques.name: Palm Muting
techniques.description: Critical for the 'choppy fuzz tone' described in contemporary reviews. Creates the percussive, tight sound characteristic of early 80s rock.

details.technique: Rest palm edge lightly on strings near bridge
details.application: Use throughout verse and chorus rhythm parts
details.soundGoal: Tight, percussive attack without ringing sustain

techniques.name: Rock Strumming Patterns
techniques.description: Steady eighth-note patterns with emphasis on beats 1 and 3. Down-down-up-down-up pattern creates the driving rhythm.

techniques.name: Basic Lead Guitar
techniques.description: Solo section requires intermediate to advanced lead techniques including bends, hammer-ons, and melodic phrasing in E major.

sections.name: Intro
sections.description: Eight-bar introduction featuring the main E5-B5-A5 power chord progression with palm-muted attack.
notes: Start with clean attack, build intensity
Palm muting throughout for choppy sound

sections.name: Verse 1
sections.description: Sixteen-bar verse section using the same power chord progression, supporting lead vocals with rhythmic foundation.

sections.name: Chorus
sections.description: Eight-bar chorus featuring the signature 'Hurt so good' vocal hook over driving power chord progression.

sections.name: Verse 2
sections.description: Second verse with slight variations in rhythm guitar approach, building toward bridge section.
notes: Similar to Verse 1 but with subtle variations

sections.name: Chorus 2
sections.description: Second chorus with fuller arrangement, leading into the bridge/solo section.

sections.name: Bridge/Solo
sections.description: Sixteen-bar instrumental bridge featuring guitar solo over the main chord progression. Advanced techniques required.
notes: Solo uses E major pentatonic scale

sections.name: Final Chorus
sections.description: Final chorus with maximum energy and full band arrangement.

sections.name: Outro
sections.description: Extended outro section returning to main riff pattern with gradual fade.
sections.progression: E5 - E5 - B5 - A5 (repeat and fade)

guitar.pickup: Humbucker or single-coil pickups work well

beginner.title: Basic power chord shapes and simple strumming
skills: Learn E5, B5, and A5 power chord shapes
Work on palm muting technique slowly

intermediate.title: Full rhythm guitar performance with proper technique
skills: Master the complete rhythm guitar part
Learn to play along with original recording

advanced.title: Lead guitar solo and performance polish
skills: Learn the complete guitar solo section
Master E major pentatonic scale (12th fret position)
Develop bending, hammer-on, and pull-off techniques
Work on solo phrasing and expression
Combine rhythm and lead parts for complete performance

commonMistakes: Not using enough palm muting - loses the characteristic 'choppy' sound
Rushing the tempo - 128 BPM should feel steady and controlled
Power chord fingering too tense - keep hand relaxed for clean changes
Not emphasizing beats 1 and 3 - loses the driving rock feel
Solo section too fast - focus on clean phrasing over speed
practiceRoutine: Start with slow power chord changes (80 BPM)
Add palm muting once chord changes are clean
Practice with metronome at target tempo (128 BPM)
Play along with original recording for timing
Work on solo section separately before combining
metronomeWork: Begin practice at 80-90 BPM for technique development
Gradually increase to 100 BPM for comfortable playing
Target tempo: 128 BPM for performance level
Practice emphasis on beats 1 and 3 with metronome accents
Use subdivision practice (quarter notes, then eighth notes)
